image.altText: an orange map with faces of northern territory people popping out

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory has the highest proportion of Indigenous people out of all the states and territories. This is what they think of the Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: This is what Indigenous Australians in remote NT communities think of the Voice

image.altText: Blacklisted Research

props.synopsis: An obscure 1980s documentary about the Indigenous land rights movement has become a clarion call for those opposing the Voice to Parliament. An ABC Investigations analysis has traced how a debunked conspiracy theory about communists was weaponised to divide voters on the referendum.

title.children: How white supremacists used an obscure 40-year-old documentary to split the Voice vote

image.altText: a man wearing swimmers sits on the side of a harbour pool in sydney while looking at this phone

props.synopsis: The ABC's national weather wrap is back, as our meteorologist Tom Saunders breaks down why the declaration of El Niño and a positive Indian Ocean Dipole doesn't guarantee a dry summer.

title.children: El Niño summers show no swing towards wet or dry for majority of Australia

image.altText: A portrait of Troy Hunt in greyscale with only the Gold Coast skyline reflection in his sunglasses in colour

props.synopsis: He's just "a dude on the web", but Troy Hunt has ended up playing an oddly central role in global cybersecurity.

title.children: This Gold Coast man has built the world's largest known repository of stolen data

image.altText: Penny Wong, wearing a blue jacket, speaks into a microphone in front of a large sloping window.

props.synopsis: The Foreign Minister puts a focus on conflict, climate change and nuclear weapons in a speech at the United Nations General Assembly, calling for reforms to the UN to better respond to an "age of existential threats".

title.children: Australia accuses Russia of mocking the UN as Penny Wong calls for changes to how it works

image.altText: A man looks at the camera, with his hands raised and palms facing the camera

props.synopsis: Russell Brand has spent years standing in the space between conspiracy theories and wellness online — this is why he wants you there with him.

title.children: Russell Brand's pivot from mainstream comedian to fringe conspiracy theorist is a textbook power play

image.altText: A composite image of Malcolm Turnbull, Rupert Murdoch and Kevin Rudd

props.synopsis: It's a well worn path for Australian prime ministers to meet with the world's most powerful person while in the United States. They also usually meet with the US president, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: The mogul and the powerful men who court him: How Murdoch maintained a grip on Australian politics

image.altText: A close up photo of Natasha Fyles with a serious expression

props.synopsis: Natasha Fyles has taken aim at "attention-seeking senators" for criticising the $1.5 billion taxpayer-funded Middle Arm industrial hub, in a speech to the territory's business community.

title.children: 'Senators on a soapbox': NT chief minister slams Middle Arm industrial hub opponents

image.altText: Posters with the image of Sikh leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar

props.synopsis: India suspends new visas for Canadians and asks Ottawa to reduce its diplomatic presence in the country, as tensions between the two nations grow following a Sikh separatist's murder.

title.children: 'Safe haven for terrorists': India escalates spat against Canada, suspending new visas

image.altText: Candace, a young woman with brown hair, sits on a grey couch wearing head-to-toe black with crochet flowers

props.synopsis: Candace Powell wanted to lose herself in something ... but didn't want that thing to be her phone. Then she was reminded she technically knew how to crochet and knit.

title.children: 'Blown away by how peaceful and satisfying it was': The life lessons I've learnt from knitting and crochet

image.altText: A woman looking at her kindle

props.synopsis: As China's economy remains in the doldrums, more and more young people see social media influencer as a legitimate career option, but experts question the industry's sustainability.

title.children: Rainbow quit her job to become a full-time social media influencer and now earns up to $20,000 a month

image.altText: Huge plumes of smoke from a bushfire rising about bushland.

props.synopsis: The 37-year-old man has been arrested and charged with lighting 18 bushfires in the NT's Top End region, with police trying to establish if he was connected to more than 60 others.

title.children: Alleged arsonist charged with deliberately lighting 18 blazes during extreme NT bushfire season

image.altText: A pool toy floating in a backyard pool.

props.synopsis: Coroner Elisabeth Armitage is recommending the Northern Territory government update its swimming pool safety laws, following the drowning death of a two-year-old.

title.children: 'Children deserve better': NT coroner releases findings on toddler's drowning

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, left, and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arrive at a signing ceremony.

props.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy offers a heartfelt thanks to Canada for its help in the war against Russia, saying Ottawa's aid had helped save thousands of lives.

title.children: Zelenskyy speaks in Canada after Ukraine strikes Russia's navy base in Crimea

image.altText: A composite image of James, Elisabeth, Lachlan and Chloe Murdoch.

props.synopsis: Media magnate Rupert Murdoch has announced that he is stepping away from the empire he created, saying he will turn over the reins to his son Lachlan.

title.children: Who's who? Here's the Murdoch family tree to bring you up to date

image.altText: Jordan De Goey holds his arms up and smiles in the Collingwood dressing room

props.synopsis: The Pies are through to the grand final after a stellar Jordan De Goey performance headlined an amazing victory over the Giants  — but it's not all good news for Collingwood. Here are five quick hits.

title.children: Five quick hits — A maligned Collingwood superstar dominates, but an injury hits the Pies at the wrong time

image.altText: Callum Ah Chee leaps towards Dayne Zorko in celebration

props.synopsis: Brisbane Lions' Callum Ah Chee is two wins and potentially just eight days away from becoming the first Australian man with Chinese heritage to win a flag.

title.children: Callum Ah Chee on the cusp of 141-year first for football's Chinese-Australian community

image.altText: A close up of a small brown mammal covered in brown scales.

props.synopsis: Former Australian police officer Stephen Carmody is working with an anti-wildlife crime group to fight pangolin trafficking. And he's helping catch some big targets.

title.children: How a former Australian cop is helping bust pangolin smuggling

image.altText: A group of rugby league players celebrate a try

props.synopsis: With the Panthers gearing up for yet another premiership, Ivan Cleary's side should be eyeing a place among the greatest teams ever to play their sport.

title.children: One more win and Penrith can lay claim as the greatest team in rugby league's history

image.altText: Two rugby league players face off during a match

props.synopsis: Referee Adam Gee lays down the law early in the NRL preliminary final, before the Panthers lay down a smashing of the Melbourne Storm as Penrith made a fourth-straight NRL grand final.

title.children: Five quick hits — lines were drawn, mistakes were made, and the Panthers are in the grand final

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair poses for a portrait photo as she wears pink lipstick and a sparkly black top

props.synopsis: Kate Miller-Heidke and Keir Nuttall's new musical comedy, Bananaland, considers the best way to deliver a political message at a moment of planetary crisis.

title.children: How listening to The Wiggles' Big Red Car 500 times inspired Kate Miller-Heidke's new musical comedy

image.altText: Bjorn Again

props.synopsis: One of the most successful ABBA tribute acts of all time says beyond having strong vocals and bright costumes, incorporating "satire and parody" is key to cutting through with fans.

title.children: Tribute acts 'get a lot of heat' but musicians say it's 'all about having fun'

image.altText: Qantas Group CEO Vanessa Hudson wearing a yellow top with trees behind her in public apology video

props.synopsis: Qantas' new CEO issues a public apology for a series of scandals that have damaged the airline's reputation, acknowledging it has been "hard to deal with" and promising to make changes to rebuild customer trust.

title.children: New Qantas boss publicly apologises for letting travelling public down

image.altText: A woman holds her stomach which has a baby in it and leans on a tree.

props.synopsis: Working full-time, recently married and pregnant, Maria and her partner never thought they wouldn't be able to find a home. But amid the rental crisis that's plaguing Australia, living in a tent was their only option.

title.children: Maria came from Colombia with big dreams of Australia. Now she's pregnant and living in a tent near Darwin

image.altText: An US senator wearing black suit and blue tie surrounded by people.

props.synopsis: US Senator Bob Menendez of New Jersey and his wife were indicted Friday on charges they took bribes of cash, gold bars and a luxury car for a range of corrupt acts.

title.children: US Senator Bob Menendez and wife charged with bribery as probe finds $154,000 in gold bars

image.altText: Two F1 drivers, one giving a thumbs up, stand on a podium, smiling and celebrating.

props.synopsis: There are seven races left in the 2023 season and this weekend's Japanese Grand Prix is Red Bull's first opportunity to secure the constructors' championship.

title.children: What Red Bull needs to do to win F1's world title this weekend

image.altText: Sylvie Ayer Conservation (Hope) Photographer of the Year winner

props.synopsis: An image of a paper nautilus — a type of octopus — floating on a piece of ocean debris comes out on top of 8,000 entries.

title.children: Dugongs, sharks and a 'paper nautilus' — the winning images from the Ocean Photographer of the Year competition
